description: Welcome to the CompTIA CySA+ series. This series is intended to explore the topics necessary to prepare for the CySA+ exam. Here we cover many computer security related concepts and tools, exploring their best practices and practical application. This includes threats, threat management, reconnaissance, and countermeasures, common vulnerabilities, penetration testing, incident response, security architectures, and common tool sets.
descriptionMD: Welcome to the CompTIA CySA+ series. This series is intended to explore the topics necessary to prepare for the CySA+ exam. Here we cover many computer security related concepts and tools, exploring their best practices and practical application. This includes threats, threat management, reconnaissance, and countermeasures, common vulnerabilities, penetration testing, incident response, security architectures, and common tool sets.
name: CompTIA CySA+ (CS0-001)
subtitle: CompTIA Cybersecurity Analyst

episodes.description: Welcome to the CompTIA CySA+ series. This series is intended to explore the topics necessary to prepare for the CySA+ exam. Here we cover many computer security related concepts and tools, exploring their best practices and practical application. This includes threats, threat management, reconnaissance, and countermeasures, common vulnerabilities, penetration testing, incident response, security architectures, and common tool sets.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.750
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.700 --> 00:00:07.402
Hello, and thank you for watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:07.402 --> 00:00:11.238
With us is Daniel Lowrie, and
we're talking about CySA+.

4
00:00:11.238 --> 00:00:12.785
Daniel, can you tell us what
this course is all about?

5
00:00:12.785 --> 00:00:13.970
>> I sure can.

6
00:00:13.970 --> 00:00:19.216
Today, we're gonna talk about CySA+, which
is the CompTIA's cybersecurity analyst

7
00:00:19.216 --> 00:00:24.290
plus certification, and it is
a certification based around security,

8
00:00:24.290 --> 00:00:27.200
right, because it's part of
cybersecurity analyst, right,

9
00:00:27.200 --> 00:00:30.040
and we're going to talk about a lot of
interesting things when it comes to that.

10
00:00:30.040 --> 00:00:33.316
It gives you a couple of domains
that are inside of that,

11
00:00:33.316 --> 00:00:37.989
that reasearch out to things like
incident response, and threat management,

12
00:00:37.989 --> 00:00:42.731
and being able to analyze and work with
the different type of security issues that

13
00:00:42.731 --> 00:00:45.685
you might encounter as
a cybersecurity analyst.

14
00:00:45.685 --> 00:00:49.479
I wanna cover that from soup to nuts,
and that's what they attempt to do with

15
00:00:49.479 --> 00:00:50.360
the CySA+.
>> So

16
00:00:50.360 --> 00:00:53.660
who is this show targeted towards?
>> This show is targeted toward people

17
00:00:53.660 --> 00:00:57.310
that actually have some experience
with systems administration,

18
00:00:57.310 --> 00:00:58.510
network administration.

19
00:00:58.510 --> 00:01:02.077
It is not for
the brand spanking new green horn out

20
00:01:02.077 --> 00:01:06.084
there that just gotten past
their A+ certification.

21
00:01:06.084 --> 00:01:10.746
You must have a bit of experience with
some security working with different

22
00:01:10.746 --> 00:01:15.565
networking tools, operating system tools,
have some familiarity there.

23
00:01:15.565 --> 00:01:20.568
So you do have to have some experience
in the field, not required per say,

24
00:01:20.568 --> 00:01:26.139
if you were motivated, you could probably
study all of these different things and

25
00:01:26.139 --> 00:01:28.963
pass the exam, but it sure does help, and

26
00:01:28.963 --> 00:01:33.888
it is geared toward people that have
been out there working in the field as

27
00:01:33.888 --> 00:01:38.490
a system and/or network administrator,
maybe even some security

28
00:01:38.490 --> 00:01:43.656
responsibilities as well to go along
with that, and then to prove that set of

29
00:01:43.656 --> 00:01:46.656
knowledge you go and you take the CySA+.
>> All

30
00:01:46.656 --> 00:01:49.364
right, so I was just going to say, is
there a certification involved with this

31
00:01:49.364 --> 00:01:49.998
exam?
>> There is.

32
00:01:49.998 --> 00:01:51.550
This is no tech skill.

33
00:01:51.550 --> 00:01:56.460
This is an actual cert, and
you will get a lovely minted piece of

34
00:01:56.460 --> 00:02:00.460
paper that has your name on it, says
that you have passed successfully, and

35
00:02:00.460 --> 00:02:04.290
you are certified in these
technologies and techniques.

36
00:02:04.290 --> 00:02:06.861
If we want to,
we can actually go to CompTIA's website,

37
00:02:06.861 --> 00:02:10.235
which I've already pulled up on my
computer, so we can take a look at some of

38
00:02:10.235 --> 00:02:12.772
the details that they give for
us about the exam itself.

39
00:02:12.772 --> 00:02:13.570
So, let's check that out.

40
00:02:13.570 --> 00:02:16.659
Let's go to my computer,
here is the opening page, and

41
00:02:16.659 --> 00:02:20.799
all you had to do is go to
certification.comptia.org/certifications/-

42
00:02:20.799 --> 00:02:24.489
cybersecurityanalystoverview, and
there we are right there,

43
00:02:24.489 --> 00:02:28.396
well I guess you can read that,
that's just cybersecurityanalyst.

44
00:02:28.396 --> 00:02:31.573
Once we get there we get plenty
of information about this, giving

45
00:02:31.573 --> 00:02:35.557
the overview, which is right here, why is
it different, it does have this little

46
00:02:35.557 --> 00:02:39.646
blurb about the CySA+, so if you were
studying for CySA+, this is the same exam.

47
00:02:39.646 --> 00:02:43.071
They've had some legal issues that
they've had to rename and rebrand.

48
00:02:43.071 --> 00:02:44.080
Not a big deal.

49
00:02:44.080 --> 00:02:47.100
It's just the same product,
a different coat of paint, right?

50
00:02:47.100 --> 00:02:48.865
So a different name on it, not a big deal.

51
00:02:48.865 --> 00:02:51.790
Asked why is it's different, the
difference is the only intermediate high

52
00:02:51.790 --> 00:02:55.370
stakes cybersecurity analyst
certification with performance-based

53
00:02:55.370 --> 00:03:00.080
questions covering security analytics,
intrusion detection, and response.

54
00:03:00.080 --> 00:03:03.850
High stakes exam are proctored by
Pearson VUE, that's an interesting thing,

55
00:03:03.850 --> 00:03:05.710
a little factoid you need to know.

56
00:03:05.710 --> 00:03:10.928
So if you want to sign up for the exam
you'll be taking it through Pearson VUE.

57
00:03:10.928 --> 00:03:15.550
That's where you'll have to go to
actually get signed up, all right?

58
00:03:15.550 --> 00:03:16.578
The testing centers and

59
00:03:16.578 --> 00:03:20.119
the CySA+ is the is the most up to date
security analyst certification that covers

60
00:03:20.119 --> 00:03:23.684
advanced persistent threats in
a post-2014 server security environment.

61
00:03:23.684 --> 00:03:27.484
There's their rundown, giving us more
information about the exam, some

62
00:03:27.484 --> 00:03:32.144
certification pathways, this is actually a
really interesting infographic right here.

63
00:03:32.144 --> 00:03:35.950
So, it's telling you about
core skills certification.

64
00:03:35.950 --> 00:03:41.709
Here we start off with IT fundamentals,
moving on to A+, and then to Network+,

65
00:03:41.709 --> 00:03:47.217
and to Security+, to show you where this
falls in line in the pathway to CASP,

66
00:03:47.217 --> 00:03:52.657
which is advanced, and then probably
on to something like CISSP after that.

67
00:03:52.657 --> 00:03:58.716
But here you see in the intermediate
scope you have PenTest+ and CySA+.

68
00:03:58.716 --> 00:04:02.759
So where PenTest+ is geared toward
things like red teaming and attack,

69
00:04:02.759 --> 00:04:07.329
trying to PenTesters, that's where they
will wanna go if you were on the blue team

70
00:04:07.329 --> 00:04:10.906
defender systems,
that's what you would want that CySA+, so

71
00:04:10.906 --> 00:04:14.172
that's where we're looking
to get into cybersecurity.

72
00:04:14.172 --> 00:04:17.423
As a defender,
I need to be able to short my systems, so

73
00:04:17.423 --> 00:04:20.252
CySA+ is a great exam for
that test the skills or

74
00:04:20.252 --> 00:04:24.240
learn new skills that you need to
know be successful in that arena.

75
00:04:25.710 --> 00:04:27.923
Let's go ahead and zoom back out,
and we'll keep scrolling down.

76
00:04:27.923 --> 00:04:29.040
What skills will you learn?

77
00:04:29.040 --> 00:04:29.996
Threat management.

78
00:04:29.996 --> 00:04:30.599
All right.

79
00:04:30.599 --> 00:04:34.253
Apply environment reconnaissance
techniques using appropriate tools,

80
00:04:34.253 --> 00:04:37.446
analyzing results, and
implementing recommended responses.

81
00:04:37.446 --> 00:04:38.990
We have vulnerability management.

82
00:04:38.990 --> 00:04:40.870
Implement vulnerability
management processes and

83
00:04:40.870 --> 00:04:46.085
analyze the results of vulnerability scan,
secure architecture and

84
00:04:46.085 --> 00:04:49.770
toolsets, these are the different
things that we are going to do and

85
00:04:49.770 --> 00:04:54.546
employ to make sure that our systems are
secure, even working through the software

86
00:04:54.546 --> 00:04:58.640
development lifecycle, well I'm going
to secure coding best practices.

87
00:04:58.640 --> 00:05:02.266
Cyber incident responses is if
the worst does happen how do we handle

88
00:05:02.266 --> 00:05:03.166
the situation?

89
00:05:03.166 --> 00:05:05.504
They want to make sure that
you're prepared for that, so

90
00:05:05.504 --> 00:05:08.530
they add cyber incident response as
one of the skills that you will learn.

91
00:05:09.560 --> 00:05:12.670
All right, then some of the organizations
that contribute to the development of

92
00:05:12.670 --> 00:05:16.820
CySA, Northrop Grumman,
Ricoh, which makes printers.

93
00:05:16.820 --> 00:05:20.853
Target, I'm sure that they were quick to
jump on the bandwagon after their data

94
00:05:20.853 --> 00:05:24.522
breach, to say, you know what,
cybersecurity is an important thing,

95
00:05:24.522 --> 00:05:28.217
we should probably do something with that,
and of course, Dell, LPI.

96
00:05:28.217 --> 00:05:32.570
Jobs that use CompTIA,
CySA+: IT Security Analyst.

97
00:05:32.570 --> 00:05:35.980
So, if youâ€™re looking at job postings,
these are the types of job listing you

98
00:05:35.980 --> 00:05:40.400
would look for if you are successful
in obtaining the CySA+.

99
00:05:40.400 --> 00:05:45.283
So, IT security analyst, vulnerability
analyst, threat intelligence analyst,

100
00:05:45.283 --> 00:05:49.691
cybersecurity analysts, secure
operations center, or SOC analysts, and

101
00:05:49.691 --> 00:05:52.700
cybersecurity specialist and
security engineer.

102
00:05:52.700 --> 00:05:55.956
Those will be all the types
of jobs you wanna look for.

103
00:05:55.956 --> 00:06:01.112
That is the basic rundown though of
what you can expect to learn and

104
00:06:01.112 --> 00:06:05.148
be tested on when it comes to CySA+.
>> Thanks Daniel.

105
00:06:05.148 --> 00:06:08.370
Now, if CySA+ sounds like something you
might be interested in, and it sure should

106
00:06:08.370 --> 00:06:13.010
be, make sure you watch every single
episode of CySA+ in our course library.

107
00:06:13.010 --> 00:06:15.923
Thank you for watching ITProTV,
we are binge worthy, thanks.

108
00:06:15.923 --> 00:06:21.711
[MUSIC]

episodes.description:
In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie look into some of the common
tools utilized by a Cybersecurity Analyst during many of their day-to-day
operations. Here you will learn about tools like vulnerability scanners,
host discovery scanners, packet analyzers, firewalls, and logging systems.
episodes.title: Reconnaissance: Tools

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie look into some of the common tools utilized by a Cybersecurity Analyst during many of their day-to-day operations. Here you will learn about tools like vulnerability scanners, host discovery scanners, packet analyzers, firewalls, and logging systems.
episodes.title: Reconnaissance: Tools Part 2

episodes.description:
In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie look into some of the common
tools utilized by a Cybersecurity Analyst during many of their day-to-day
operations. Here you will learn about tools like vulnerability scanners.
episodes.title: Reconnaissance: Tools Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie look into some of the common tools utilized by a Cybersecurity Analyst during many of their day-to-day operations. Here you will learn about tools like vulnerability scanners, host discovery scanners, packet analyzers, firewalls, and logging systems.
episodes.title: Reconnaissance: Tools Part 4

episodes.description:
In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie look into some of the common
techniques utilized by a Cybersecurity Analyst during many of their day-to-day
operations focused on reconnaissance. Here you will learn about techniques such
as considerations of variables, topology mapping, OS fingerprinting, log review,
email harvesting, DNS harvesting, social engineering, and phishing.
episodes.title: Reconnaissance: Techniques

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie look into some of the common techniques utilized by a Cybersecurity Analyst during many of their day-to-day operations focused on reconnaissance. Here you will learn about techniques such as considerations of variables, topology mapping, OS fingerprinting, log review, email harvesting, DNS harvesting, social engineering, and phishing.
episodes.title: Reconnaissance: Techniques Part 2

episodes.description:
In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie look into some of the common
techniques utilized by a Cybersecurity Analyst during many of their day-to-day
operations focused on reconnaissance. Here you will learn about techniques such
as considerations of variables, topology mapping, OS fingerprinting, log review,
email harvesting, DNS harvesting, social engineering, and phishing.
episodes.title: Reconnaissance: Techniques Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie look into some of the common techniques utilized by a Cybersecurity Analyst during many of their day-to-day operations focused on reconnaissance. Here you will learn about techniques such as considerations of variables, topology mapping, OS fingerprinting, log review, email harvesting, DNS harvesting, social engineering, and phishing.
episodes.title: Reconnaissance: Techniques Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie look into some of the common techniques utilized by a Cybersecurity Analyst during many of their day-to-day operations focused on reconnaissance. Here you will look into analyzing and interpreting the results of reconnaissance data; starting with understanding point-in-time analysis as well as data correlation and analysis types.
episodes.title: Data Correlation and Analytics

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie look into some of the common techniques utilized by a Cybersecurity Analyst during many of their day-to-day operations focused on reconnaissance. Here you will learn how to interpret the results of scans and logs to check for possible security issues.
episodes.title: Reconnaissance: Interpreting Results

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the different responses and countermeasures that can be employed to protect against network based attacks. Here they will cover network segmentation strategies, specifically the use of system isolation. This will cover the pros and cons of system isolation and then explore the use of Jump Boxes and Secure Admin Workstations.
episodes.title: Countermeasures: Network Segmentation

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the different responses and countermeasures that can be employed to protect against network based attacks. Here they look into using Honeypots and DNS Sinkholes to that end. Honeypots to help reveal how a network is being targeted/attacked and Sinkholes which can be an effective tactic for stoping malware from connecting to Command&Control servers.
episodes.title: Countermeasures: Honeypots and Sinkholes

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the different responses and countermeasures that can be employed to protect against network based attacks. Here they look at employing system hardening techniques like Mandatory Access Controls(MAC) and compensating controls. They also explore endpoint security like Antivirus, Microsoft Windows Group Policy, and Network Access Control(NAC).
episodes.title: Countermeasures: System Hardening and NAC

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach dive into the purpose of specific practices used to secure a corporate environment. Here they will discuss penetration testing, looking into its purpose, strategies of implementation, rules of engagement, and reporting of results.
episodes.title: Security Practices: Penetration Testing

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach dive into the purpose of specific practices used to secure a corporate environment. Here they will discuss reverse engineering, specifically touching on defining, tactics, and safety precautions when engaging in reverse engineering.
episodes.title: Security Practices: Reverse Engineering

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach dive into the purpose of specific practices used to secure a corporate environment. Here they will discuss risk evaluation and training. They begin with common training techniques and exercises that help bolster skills for security professionals while verifying that security controls are performing as expected. Then they move onto risk evaluation and likelihood.
episodes.title: Security Practices: Training and Risk Evaluation

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach discuss and explore implementing an Information Security Vulnerability Management Process. Here they define a vulnerability management process and look into identifying any regulatory requirements or corporate policies that would aid in guiding that process. They also discuss data classification and asset inventory.
episodes.title: Vulnerability Management Process

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach discuss and explore implementing an Information Security Vulnerability Management Process. Specifically they look at common configuration settings found in many vulnerability scanning suites.
episodes.title: Vulnerability Management: Scan Configuration

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach discuss and explore implementing an Information Security Vulnerability Management Process. Here they focus on understanding the Common Vulnerability Scoring System that is used to rate the impact of vulnerabilities discovered when scanning.
episodes.title: Vulnerability Management CVSS

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach discuss and explore implementing an Information Security Vulnerability Management Process. Here they focus on understanding the Common Vulnerability Scoring System that is used to rate the impact of vulnerabilities discovered when scanning.
episodes.title: Vulnerability Management: CVSS Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach discuss and explore implementing an Information Security Vulnerability Management Process. Here they will look at steps you can take to remediate vulnerabilities discovered during the scanning phase as well as discuss ongoing scanning and monitoring as a regular practice.
episodes.title: Vulnerability Management: Remediation

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach walk you through the process of verifying vulnerability scan results. Here they will discuss identifying false positives and exceptions then moving into practical verification of reported vulnerabilities, even showing a demonstration of that process.
episodes.title: Scan Results Verification

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach explore many of the common vulnerabilities that must be understood by a cyber security practitioner. Here they will give explanations to vulnerabilities against servers, workstations, and network infrastructure. Specifically they cover vulnerabilities common to Servers and endpoints like missing patches, buffer overflows, privilege escalation, and remote code execution.
episodes.title: Common Vulnerabilities

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach explore many of the common vulnerabilities that must be understood by a cyber security practitioner. Here they will give explanations to vulnerabilities against servers, workstations, and network infrastructure. Specifically they cover insecure protocols, Certificate issues, and DNS related vulnerabilities.
episodes.title: Common Vulnerabilities Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore many of the common vulnerabilities that must be understood by a cyber security practitioner. Here they will give explanations to vulnerabilities against servers, workstations, and network infrastructure. Specifically they cover Network Appliances like routers, firewall, and switches.
episodes.title: Common Vulnerabilities Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore many of the common vulnerabilities that must be understood by a cyber security practitioner. Here they will give explanations to vulnerabilities against servers, workstations, and network infrastructure. Specifically they cover vulnerabilities common to wireless access points and clients.
episodes.title: Common Vulnerabilities Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore many of the common vulnerabilities that must be understood by a cyber security practitioner. Here they will give explanations to vulnerabilities against servers, workstations, and network infrastructure. Specifically they cover vulnerabilities in Virtual infrastructure, mobile devices, and ISC/SCADA systems.
episodes.title: Common Vulnerabilities Part 5

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike start working through the Incident Response domain of the CySA+ exam objectives. Here they take a look at threat classification; beginning by generalizing threat types and then classifying them further into based of their specific attributes.
episodes.title: Threat Classification

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike tackle defining incident severity and prioritization. Here they will look at different impact scopes like functional impact, data integrity impact, and economic impact as well as discussing the different types of data that could lend to the impact severity. This includes Personally Identifiable Information(PII), Personal Health Information(PHI), Payment Card Information, and Intellectual Property.
episodes.title: Severity and Prioritization

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike look into what can commonly be found in a modern forensics toolkit. This include tools like digital forensic workstation, write blockers, various cables (usb,network,Lightning), drive adapters, removable media, tamper-proof seals, and standard documentation/forms.
episodes.title: Forensics Toolkit

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore what goes into putting together an Incident Response Plan. Here you will learn each of the phases like Preparation, Detection and Analysis, Containment and Recovery, and Post-Incident activity. You will also learn how to develop a successful Incident Playbook.
episodes.title: Incident Response Plan

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike guide you through looking at many of the cybersecurity forensic suites and utilities used during Incidence Response. Here they specifically cover analysis utilities like the Forensic Toolkit, forensic Operating Systems like CAINE, and imaging utilities such as dd and the FTK Imager.
episodes.title: Forensic Suites and Utilities

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike guide you through looking at many of the cybersecurity forensic suites and utilities used during Incidence Response. Here they specifically look at Data Carving utilities like Foremost and Bulk Extractor as well as how to look for hidden data in alternate data stream(ADS).
episodes.title: Forensic Suites and Utilities Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike guide you through looking at many of the cybersecurity forensic suites and utilities used during Incidence Response. Here they specifically cover data recovery from Memory Dumps, chain of custody, and data integrity verification through hashing.
episodes.title: Forensic Suites and Utilities Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike guide you through looking at many of the cybersecurity forensic suites and utilities used during Incidence Response. Here they specifically cover OS and Process analysis tools, Mobile device forensics, password crackers, and log viewers.
episodes.title: Forensic Suites and Utilities Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore what it takes to put together a successful Computer Security Incident Response Team(CSIRT). Here they will explain the key stakeholders and technical team members including their roles and responsibilities. Also they discuss the purpose of the communication process.
episodes.title: CSIRT Roles and Communication

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain common network related symptoms and indicators of compromise. These symptoms include high Bandwidth consumption, beaconing, irregular peer-to-peer communication, rogue devices, scan sweeps, and unusual network traffic spikes.
episodes.title: Indicator of Compromise: Network Symptoms

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore host and application based symptoms and indicators of compromise. These symptoms include processor/memory/network/drive consumption, malicious processes, discovery of unknown accounts, service interruption, and memory overflows.
episodes.title: Indicators of Compromise: Host and App Symptoms

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike dive into Recovery and Post-Incident response. Here they discuss containment and eradication techniques as well as OS Reconstruction/Reimage and safe drive destruction techniques.
episodes.title: Recovery and Post-Incident Response

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike dive into Recovery and Post-Incident response. Here they go over recover validation, corrective actions, and incident summary reporting to help prevent similar incidents in the future.
episodes.title: Recovery and Post-Incident Response Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Jo explore the different cybersecurity frameworks that are relevant to the CySA+ exam. Here they discuss the NIST Framework for Improving Critical Infrastructure Cybersecurity, the ISO 27001 framework, COBIT, SABSA, TOGAF, and ITIL.
episodes.title: Cybersecurity Frameworks

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Jo explore the different cybersecurity frameworks that are relevant to the CySA+ exam. Here they discuss the NIST Framework for Improving Critical Infrastructure Cybersecurity, the ISO 27001 framework, COBIT, SABSA, TOGAF, and ITIL.
episodes.title: Cybersecurity Frameworks Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes walk you through policies, controls, and procedures. Here they look specifically at Regulatory Compliances, as well as tackling what makes up a organizational cybersecurity Policy. This includes things like password policies, acceptable use policies, data ownership, data retention, account management, and data classification.
episodes.title: Policies, Controls and Procedures

episodes.description:
In this episode, Daniel and Wes walk you through policies, controls, and procedures. Here they continue by looking at Security Controls  
discussing both physical and logical controls. Then they move on to Procedures, exploring the best-practices for creating step-by-step implementations of security Controls. Finally, they explain verification and quality control to help make sure that you're attaining and maintaining your security goals.
episodes.title: Policies, Controls and Procedures Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore security when dealing with Identity and Access Management systems. Here they cover context-based authentication issues, issues associated with identities, and issues associated with identity repositories.
episodes.title: Identity and Access Managemnt

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore security when dealing with Identity and Access Management systems. Here they continue discussing issues with identity repositories then move on to security issues associated with federation and single sign-on. Finally, they look over some common exploits that are focused towards Identities.
episodes.title: Identity and Access Management Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike take a look at what goes into implementing compensating controls and secure network architecture. Here they begin by exploring security data analytics like data aggregation/correlation, trend analysis, and historical analysis. Then they tackle manual log review as a way of discerning attempts to compromise.
episodes.title: Compensating Controls and Architecture

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike take a look at what goes into implementing compensating controls and secure network architecture. Here they cover the concept and practice of Defense in Depth, specifically focused on dealing with the human element within organizations; exploring how to enhance inherent security through various means.
episodes.title: Compensating Controls and Architecture Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike take a look at what goes into implementing compensating controls and secure network architecture. Here they finish their conversation by covering the Process lifecycle, common security technologies implemented to increase the security architecture of a network, and logical design implementations that focus on increasing security.
episodes.title: Compensating Controls and Architecture Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike run you through the litany of security tools and technologies that you'll need to be familiar with for the CySA+ exam. You will need to be familiar with the categories that each tool or techniques fall under, but you will not need to have working knowledge of any feature set with regards to the tools mentioned.
episodes.title: Security Tools and Technologies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike run you through the litany of security tools and technologies that you'll need to be familiar with for the CySA+ exam. You will need to be familiar with the categories that each tool or techniques fall under, but you will not need to have working knowledge of any feature set with regards to the tools mentioned.
episodes.title: Security Tools and Technologies Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach run you through the litany of security tools and technologies that you'll need to be familiar with for the CySA+ exam. You will need to be familiar with the categories that each tool or techniques fall under, but you will not need to have working knowledge of any feature set with regards to the tools mentioned.
episodes.title: Security Tools and Technologies Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach discuss software development security best-practices. Here they cover security requirements definition, security testing phases, manual peer-reviews, User Acceptance Testing, and application stress-testing.
episodes.title: Software Development Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Zach discuss software development security best-practices. Here they cover security regression testing, input validation, and secure coding best-practices as developed by OWASP, SANS, and the Center for Internet Security.
episodes.title: Software Development Security Part 2
